awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this award is to fund a meeting for materials researchers in the realm of 2 dimensional materials to envision how data sciences can contribute to the development of this discipline to elucidate structure/processing/property correlations. At present, many materials problems of technological relevance suffer from lack of data frameworks. Indeed, lack of adequate frameworks to process, curate, and share complex raw data hinders progress in this field, ultimately not realizing the promise of 2 dimensional materials commercial technologies.  In short, materials scientists are inundated with multi-dimensional data from many sources, both experimental and computational, and vast amounts of data are under-utilized, repeatedly acquired, or thrown out completely. 
The purpose of this workshop is to build the needed framework towards sound data schemes and repositories in the realm of 2 dimensional materials.

This meeting is the first intervention on the PIs of the recently constituted NSF-2D Data Framework (2DDF), which will be complemented by further PI meetings as well as events for students and post-docs to provide training and implement the vision developed by PIs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled the creation and execution of several events for the materials research community in relation to DMR-supported centers and their data curation efforts. First, a half-day workshop on the benefits and need of effective data curation and metadata for PIs of DMR-2D research groups was organized by the Platform for the Accelerated Realization, Analysis, and Discovery of Interface Materials (PARADIM), an NSF Materials Innovation Platform (MIP) Grant No. DMR-1539918, and held on November 25th, 2018. All presentations, and a recording of the presentations and key discussions of the first installment of the workshop in 2018 continue to be publicly available at http://www.paradim.org/events/dmr2d_MRS_2018. The workshop kicked off the DMR-2D data framework effort, laying the foundation for follow-up data workshops, including a virtual data meeting at the Spring 2019 MRS organized by the 2DCC-MIP, and the November 2019 Summit on Big Data and Cyberinfrastructure in Materials Research. In Fall 2021, the 1st NSF-DMR Materials Innovations Platform Forum was held during the 2021 Fall Meeting of the Materials Research Society in Boston, MA. The half-day hybrid event was attended by over 130 researchers (~60 onsite in Boston and 74 via Zoom webinar) and included 6 user success story presentations, as well as flash talks highlighting recent research and upcoming upgrades at the 2016 MIPs. The newest members of the family of MIPs, BioPACIFIC MIP and GlycoMIP that had been awarded in 2020, presented their platforms’ scientific focus, capabilities, and modes of access. All headline presentations of the event are publicly available at https://www.paradim.org/MIP_Forum_MRS_2021. Participants used the occasion to network, share their experiences, and discuss project ideas with scientists of all four MIPs.

In summary this project created several data-centric workshops focused on the needs and interests of the materials research community. The efforts led to the formation of MaRDA, the Materials Research Data Alliance (https://www.marda-alliance.org), which is focused on developing the open, accessible, and interoperable infrastructure for materials data that fuels the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) and committed to FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and re-useable) principles.

The project brought DMR-funded PIs together to learn and discuss the benefits of effective metadata collection and data curation, and to identify key questions and challenges in further incorporating data-rich techniques into materials research. It also began the important process of community building required to develop a culture of data sharing and use. PI feedback served as input for a subsequent event: the “Community Forum on Data-Enabled Research for Two-Dimensional, Interface, and Layered Materials (2DILM) Design and Deployment.” The 2DILM Forum was held in January 2022.
